div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE
No. 7,632] ALEXANDRIA, MONDAY, DECEMBER 10, 1906. [EIGHT PAGES P.T. 1.
The Eastern Telegraph Company, Limited.
div.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

STATIONS IN EGYPT: Alexandria, Cairo,
Suez, Port-Tewfik, Port-Saïd, Suakin. Head
Office. London.
Throw Steel Nibs Away!
They waste time, are costly to use, wear out, scratch, etc.
Try a "Swan" Fountain Pen.
Prices from 10/6
Sold by all Stationers and Importers in Cairo and Alexandria.
Catalogue free.
Mable, Todd & Bard, High Holborn, London.

R.M.S. “Ophir" will leave Port Said December 31

The issue of return tickets to and from Egypt has been discontinued. Passengers paying full fare one direction will, however, be allowed abatement of one-third off fare back if return voyage be made within four months of arrival, or abatement of 20 o/o if return voyage be made within six months of arrival.
Special reduced rates during Summer season 15th May - 15th September.
Agents, Cairo: Thomas Cook & Son, Ltd. ; Alexandria : R. J. Moss & Co.

div.head: Deutsche Levante-Linie.
div.p: Mail and Passenger Steamships. Regular three-weekly Service from HAMBURG, via ANTWERP & MALTA, to ALEXANDRIA and vice-versa, admitting goods from all chief German Railway Stations on direct Bill of Landing to ALEXANDRIA and all chief ports of Egypt, Syria, etc., at favourable through rates of DEUTSCHE VERKEHR (traffic).
EXPECTED AT ALEXANDRIA.
S.S. Naxos December 13 from Hamburg.
S.S. Andros July 20 from Antwerp bound for Rott. Hamburg.
Discharging. For tariff and particulars apply to ADOLPHE STROSS, Alexandria, Agent.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 4 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez weekly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for Port Sudan and Suakin direct returning fromSuakin every Wednesday noon. Every Monday at 6 p.m. a steamer leaves Suez for Jeddah continuing every other week to Suakin, Massowah, Hodeidab, Aden. Intermediate steamers do not proceed beyond Jeddah Lat call at Tor, (for Sinai) El Wedj and yambo as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company’s Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.head: The Moss S.S. Company, Ltd.
div.p: For LIVERPOOL calling at MALTA (Messrs. JAMES MOSS & Co. 31, James St, Liverpool, Managers.)

*Second class accommodation only, unless specially reserved.—Fares : Alexandria to Liverpool, 1st, £14 Single, £25 Return. 2nd, £9 Single, £15 Return.—To Malta, 1st, £5 Single, £9 Return, 2nd, £3 Single, £5 Return.—Return tickets available for six months.
S.S. Amasia now on the berth, will sail on or about Saturday, December 15, to be followed by S.S. Menepthah

div.head: Austrian Lloyd’s Steam Navigation
div.p: Alexandria-Brindisi-Trieste (Venice).

Weekly Express Mail Service. Steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 4 p.m. arrive at Brindisi, Tuesday 5 a.m. in time for express to Milan, Lucerne, Paris, Vienna, Berlin, and London, leaving Brindisi 7 a.m. Arrival Trieste Wednesday about 11 a.m. in connection with Train de Luxe Trieste-Vienna-Ostende. Passengers reach London every Friday 4.50 p.m.
Weekly Intermediate Service: Alexandria-Brindisi & Trieste Line.
Steamer leaves Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. arrive Brindisi Sunday at 5a.m. Trieste Tuesday.
Syrian-Cyprus-Caramanian Line.
Steamer leaves Alexandria on or about 19 November, 3, 17 and 31 December.
Syrian-Caramanian Line.
Steamer leaves Alexandria on or about 26 November, 10 and 24 December.
Far East Lines.

To Suez, Aden and Bombay accelerated service about 8 December, 8 Nov.
To Suez, Aden, Karachi, Colombo, Madras, Rangoon, and Calcutta about 19 Nov, 19 Dec 4 p.m.
To Suez, Aden, Karachi and Bombay about 13 Dec.(Winter Line).
East African Line.
Departures from Port Said: To Suez, Aden, Mombassa, Zanzibar, Beira, Delagoa-Bay, and Durban about 3 Dec., 2 Nov., 3 Dec..

div.head: SUDAN GOVERNMENT RAILWAYS.
div.p: CAIRO-KHARTOUM SUMMER MAIL SERVICE.--SUMMER TIME-TABLE 1906.
Commencing from 1st of April, 1906, until further notice

‡Sleeping and Dining Cars. — During the month of April Sleeping and Dining Care trains leave Cairo for Luxor on Wednesdays, Mondays and Saturdays at 6.30 p.m. and Luxor for Cairo on Sundays, Tuesdays and Thursdays at 6.30 p.m.

From 1st of May 1908, these trains will be suppressed, but Dining and Sleeping Care will be attached to the ordinary night Tains from Cairo and Luxor three times a week, on the same above mentioned days. 14-6-907

div.head: Egyptian State Railways.
div.p: †Dining Car. §Sleeping Car. ‡First and Second Class only.
* Dining and Sleeping Cars are attached to these trains on the following days: -- From Cairo, every Monday, Wednesday and Saturday. From Luxor, every Tuesday, Thursday and Sunday.
A dining car will attached to the 11.30 a.m. Luxor to Shallal; and to the 9.10 a.m. Shallal to Luxor.
G. B. MACAULEY, General Manager.

div.head: Calvert's Carbolic Toilet Soap
div.p: Ensures a Clear, Soft Skin.

It is pure throughout, fragrantly perfumed, emollient, and antisceptic, (10% crystal carbolic). It quickly removes dust and dirt, takes away the unpleasant effects of perspiration, and leaves instead a delicious feeling of thorough purification.

div.head: EASTERN EXCHANGE HOTEL, PORT SAID.
div.p: First Class Hotel. Modern in all respects.
Fire-proof, Drained to the Sea, Lifts, Electric Light, English and French Billiards, Fresh and Salt Water Baths.
The Coolest Summer Residence in Egypt.
Special terms to Cairo Residents and their families desirous of enjoying the cool air and sea bathing during the summer months.
Dragomans in Hotel Uniform Meet all Trains and Steamers.

div.head: TEWFIK PALACE HOTEL.
div.p: HELOUAN, near CAIRO

Formerly the favourite Residence of H.H. the late Khedive. Perfect Sanitation.-Purest Desert air. Electric Light. Hot and cold baths attatched to most rooms. House warmed by special system of radiators, adjoining the Golf Links and Race Course, Tennis, Billiards, Garden and open air palm house, good stabling, dark room. Excellent Table. Moderate charges. Medical Resident Director: ARTHUR J. M. BENTLEY, M.D.-Town Office at tephenson and Co., Opera Square, Cairo.
P.E. HERGEL, Manager.

div.head: SAVOY HOTEL
div.p: LUXOR (Upper Hotel.)

Unrivalled situation. Splendid view over the Nile River. Entirely renovated. Moderate charges. Omnibus and Porter meet all trains and steamers. Special terms for Government Officials, and Officers of Army of Occupation.
Telegraphic Address:"SAVOY, LUXOR."
C and M. RUNKEWITZ, Proprietors. Also Proprietors Bean Rivage Hotel, Ramieh, Alexandria.
G. AQUILINA, Proprieter.

div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE.
div.p: SUBSCRIPTIONS.—Alexandria, Cairo, and the Interior of Egypt (including delivery in Alexandria or postage to subscriber’s address) P.T. 231½ per annum, P.T. 116 for six months, P.T. 80 for three months. To other countries in the Postal Union P.T. 273 (£2.16s.) per annum. Six months P.T. 136½ (£1.8s.), three months P.T. 92 (£0.19s.) N.B.—Subscriptions commence from the 1st or 16th of any month.

ADVERTISEMENTS.—P.T. 4 per line. Minimum charge P.T. 20. Births, Marriages, or Deaths, not exceeding three lines, P.T. 20. Every additional line P.T. 10. Notices in news column P.T. 20 per line. Contracts entered into for standing advertisements.
ADVERTISEMENTS and SUBSCRIPTIONS are due in advance. P.O. Orders and Cheques to be made payable to the Editor and Manager, Rowland Snelling, Alexandria.
London Offices : 36, New Broad-street. B.C.
THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE can be obtained in London at our office, 36, New Broad Street, E.C.
Cairo Offices.-No. 1 Sharia Vervudachi, (opposite the Agricultural Bank.)
The Egyptian Gazette
An English Daily Newspaper, Established in 1880.
Editor & Manager: R. Snelling.
Price: One Piastre Tariff.
MONDAY, DECEMBER 10,1907.
TRAFTIC IN HONOURS

It is worth noting at a moment when there is some talk about the necessity of only granting decorations and grades in Egypt for merit, that King Edward is starting a similar movement in England. "The information which we have had placed at our disposal,” says ‘The Throne” of the24thalto.,"enables us to state with authority that His Majesty views with extreme disfavour the flagrant manner in which titles have been exploited for party purposes in recent years, and will discountenance most strongly any promotions in the future which are based upon mere liberal contributions to the party funds Titles which ought to be conferred only upon men of high distinction in the realm of intellectual activity have been knocked down to the highest bidder, and these facts have not been disclosed when the name of the prospective peer has been placed before His Majesty for approval. Sir William Jones, in his famous ode in imitation of Alcseus, has given us a magnificent ideal of the State. He reminded us, in words of singular force and beauty, that it does not consist of 'starr'd and spangled courts, where low-bred baseness wafts perfume to pride,’ but of high-minded men, 'men who their duties know, but know their rights, snd, knowing, dare maintain.’ If England as a nation is to realise that ideal, the honours which she has to confer upon her distinguished sons must not be bought and sold in the political market-place, but should be preserved as a priceless reward for those whose lofty character and intellectual equipment fit them to become the forerunners of a race of statesmen.”
P. AND O. REPORT

This great company manages to pay 13 per cent. on its Deferred stock with wonderful regularity, and it is fortunate not only in having different sources of revenue, to that where one may fail another makes good the deficiency, but also in having a thoroughly business-like board of directors. It will come as no surprise to stockholders that the freight returns for the year ended September 30 do not compare favourably with those of the previous year, though the apparent deficiency is only £67,475 on a total receipt of £1,521,309, and of this £31,600 is set down to less Government work and lower rates, but the deficiency would have been greater had it not been for the earnings of certain extra voyages. Outward Indian trade was demoralised by a conflict between the English and German lines engaged in the Antwerp branch of this trade, while homeward freights from Indian ports were considerably below the normal point, and cargo was often exceptionally scarce. In Australia freights also suffered in consequence of a fall of nearly 50 per cent in the carrying rates for refrigerated produce, and the cargo fleet engaged in the local trade between India, China, and Japan was not so fully employed as in the previous year. The passenger season, however, was a good one, the total traffic of £1,087,407 being an improvement of £102,719 on last year, but the expense of working the new vessels engaged in this service, which are much larger than the ships replaced, and the further disbursements arising from the extra voyages, materially swelled the expenditure, which, apart from the sinking fund, shows an excess in the cost of navigating the fleet of upwards of £100,000, a considerable proportion of which is attributable to the acceleration of the mail service. The net result of the year's operations is really, very satisfactory, for after setting aside for depreciation £461,097 to sinking fund,the board is enabled to recommend une dividend and bonus as last year.
